thread.title: Toronto FC drops key match vs. Drogba and Impact
thread.title_full: Toronto FC drops key match vs. Drogba and Impact

title: Toronto FC drops key match vs. Drogba and Impact
text:
MONTREAL - 
Here's hoping the Montreal Sheraton has a few dozen open rooms. 
Toronto FC could be here until Thursday morning after dropping a 2-1 result to the Impact Sunday night. 
As a result, the Reds dropped from fourth- to sixth-place in the Eastern Conference and will begin these MLS playoffs on the road right here at Saputo Stadium midweek. 
Toronto's first post-season match will go Wednesday or Thursday night. 
Despite Toronto's bright start away from BMO Field for the first time in more than a month, a goal from TFC's Jozy Altidore failed to hold up. 
Didier Drogba scored twice from close range in the span of 30 seconds 10 minutes after halftime to lift the hosts into third place in the Eastern Conference. 
The goals silenced the 500 traveling TFC supporters who were in attendance here Sunday night. 
Drogba's double moved his goals total to a remarkable 11 in just nine starts this season, making him undoubtedly the most in-form attacker in the league. 
Toronto FC looked comfortable in an opening half that saw Altidore rise to meet a cross from Sebastian Giovinco in the 45th minute. 
The second half, though, was all Montreal, with Drogba striking the crossbar before converting a pair of crosses in the 55th minute. 
Toronto's Michael Bradley had a chance to rescue the Reds in the 74th but watched his effort from inside 10 metres come back off the crossbar. 
The New England Revolution will travel to D.C. United in the East's other first-round play-in match. 
If Toronto FC wins its playoff match against the Impact, it will host the New York Red Bulls Sunday night in the opening leg of the Conference Semifinals. Sponsored Links
